body:
As for the **profile locations (file paths)**:

The `$PROFILE` variable, even though it is a `[string]`, contains all profile paths as note properties; use `$PROFILE.<property>` to access a specific one (see below).

Use the following, **platform- and edition-neutral command to list all profile paths**:

```powershell
>  $PROFILE | Get-Member -Type NoteProperty | % Name | % { "$_ = $($PROFILE.$_)" }
```

### PowerShell Core 

On a **Windows** 10 machine, for instance, this yields:

```none
AllUsersAllHosts = C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0-alpha.18\profile.ps1
AllUsersCurrentHost = C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0-alpha.18\Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1
CurrentUserAllHosts = C:\Users\jdoe\Documents\PowerShell\profile.ps1
CurrentUserCurrentHost = C:\Users\jdoe\Documents\PowerShell\Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1
```

On a **macOS** machine, you'll get something like:

```none
AllUsersAllHosts = /usr/local/microsoft/powershell/6.0.0-alpha.18/profile.ps1
AllUsersCurrentHost = /usr/local/microsoft/powershell/6.0.0-alpha.18/Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1
CurrentUserAllHosts = /Users/jdoe/.config/powershell/profile.ps1
CurrentUserCurrentHost = /Users/jdoe/.config/powershell/Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1
```

On a **Linux** machine, you'll get something like:

```none
AllUsersAllHosts = /opt/microsoft/powershell/6.0.0-alpha.18/profile.ps1
AllUsersCurrentHost = /opt/microsoft/powershell/6.0.0-alpha.18/Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1
CurrentUserAllHosts = /home/jdoe/.config/powershell/profile.ps1
CurrentUserCurrentHost = /home/jdoe/.config/powershell/Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1
```

---

### Windows PowerShell v5.1

```none
AllUsersAllHosts = C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\profile.ps1
AllUsersCurrentHost = C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1
CurrentUserAllHosts = C:\Users\jdoe\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\profile.ps1
CurrentUserCurrentHost = C:\Users\jdoe\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1
```

PS1 files stored in the CurrentUserCurrentHost cannot be executed as they are not found. 
For instance a PS1 script Restart-Process.PS1 stored in C:\Users\%username%\Documents\WindowsPowerShell cannot be located:

Restart-Process : The term 'Restart-Process' is not recognized as the name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or operable program. Check the spelling of the name, or 
if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.
At line:1 char:1
+ Restart-Process
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : ObjectNotFound: (Restart-Process:String) [], CommandNotFoundException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : CommandNotFoundException
